HI I'M

TOMMI PIRTTILAHTI

I believe great user experience starts with understanding the user

My path to design


2007-2010

Tikkurila Upper Secondary School

Became interested in psychology

2011-2015

Bachelor of Science, Psychology

University of Groningen, The Netherlands

Learned about the science of human behavior and mind. Had a formal training in measuring it.

2015-2017

Master of Science, Human-Technology Interaction

University of Tampere

Established a connection with my passion of understanding humans and that of my long term interest - technology.

2017

Master's Thesis Trainee

Delta Cygni Labs

Investigated the use of gaze tracking (eye tracker) in studying user experience. Conducted a study on an augmented reality application used for remote collaboration.

2017 - present

User Insight Lead

UnSeen Technologies Ltd.

Was hired to bring my expertise in human-technology interaction to the company.

My method

I specialize in understanding human wants and needs and turning them into actionable concepts.

Customer cases

I've taken part in tens of projects in a variety of settings with various goals. Here are some of the public ones.

Cheap thermal camera A user research case (2018-)
System

UnSeen RAZR (NB-IoT)

Work done

User research + technical feasibility study

In short

UnSeen Technologies got the idea of developing a cheap, easy to setup, and wireless thermal camera system that could be used to monitor critical spots that might overheat. In order to understand if the system could work I interviewed experts in the field.
Is the camera feasible and does it have potential use cases?

Can a cheap 32x24 pixel thermal camera be used to detect heating of critical systems? Where might it be useful? These were the main questions UnSeen Technologies wanted to answer.

I prefer working from a starting point where nothing has been decided yet, but in this case we didn't have a clearly formulated hypothesis. We weren't trying to solve a problem, instead we wanted to test the feasibility of a novel solution to heat monitoring on the cheap.

Therefore, a "ducktape and bubble gum" -type of prototype was quickly put together in order to test the technical capability of the cheap thermal camera in the the field.

Power station visits

I took the prototype to a power station, where over-heating of systems can cause severe impacts to the power supply. But first I had to get licensed for Occupational safety (FI: Työturvallisuuskortti) and The Red cross first response (FI: Hätäensiapu).

While testing the feasibility, I used the opportunity to interview an expert about current ways to monitor the systems. After which, it was clear that there aren't many ways and the ways used are very resource heavy.

Visiting once isn't usually enough. For this project I visited multiple power stations to understand how they differ and how they are similar. Power stations aren't accessible to just anyone, therefore it was upto me to bring the insight back to office. Based on the gathered information we were able to iterate the prototype.

Eventually we added the possibility of wireless transfer of data

The first wireless version was straight up, bulky. Nevertheless, it was the cheapest wireless thermal camera system we knew and it worked. We were able to receive thermal images and normal images for months, with a single battery. This version wasn't even optimized for power consumption and it used a normal 4G modem to send data. Setup was also easier than originally expected, therefore we could go on to build the next version, which would again test the technical feasibility of the NB-IoT platform we had been developing.

Current situation

The latest version of the thermal cam uses the NB-IoT network, which is a low power and low speed network used for long distance data transmissions using very little power in relation to other mobile networks. The version is also very compact and can be easily put to various places.

The current prototype has several usability issues which need to be tackled, but real world test can never the less be performed to give further insight. Work is still ongoing.

City Planning map application Service redesign case (2018)
Platform

Website

Work done

User research, Interactive prototype, User testing

In short

The city of Tampere wanted a redesign of their city planning map service. The current version was not user friendly nor was it used by users. The task was to develop a new version using lean methodology, saving time and money.

User experience evaluation of an augmented reality app using gaze tracking (2017)
Platform

Mobile + desktop application

Work done

User testing, Improvement suggestions, Master's thesis

In short

As part of my thesis I investigated the use of gaze tracking in evaluating user experience. The study was based on evaluting an augmented reality application for remote collaboration

Light guided way finding system An interaction design case (2017)
System

Custom rasberry Pi demo

Work done

Interaction design, Service design

In short

As part of a university course, we were tasked on innovating with modern technology solutions at our reach. This took us on a path of rediscovering the way people can be guided to their tables at a restaurant.

Wone peer-to-peer payments application A human-centered design approach (2016)
Platform

Mobile app

Work done

User research, Interactive prototype, User testing

In short

Wone payments Oy wanted to create a peer-to-peer payment application for sharing small bills with friends.

University library online database An usability evaluation (2015)
Platform

Website

Work done

Heuristic evaluation, Usability lab evaluation

In short

The universities library had woken up to the fact that their systems were grossly outdated. Their new beta was already in testing and our job was to identify usability issues with the new system.
